awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates several questions in mathematical analysis. The topics under study are related to important areas of application, including the scattering process in electromagnetic and acoustic wave propagation, an important and ubiquitous physical phenomenon. Several of the questions concern the circle of ideas surrounding the Steklov conjecture in the theory of orthogonal polynomials.  The project also studies other questions in approximation theory and complex analysis, many of which are of central interest in probability and mathematical physics. 

A primary goal of this project is to study how the size of an orthogonal polynomial depends on the properties of the measure of orthogonality. To improve the upper estimates, the project aims to develop methods based on techniques related to singular integral operator estimates in weighted spaces. Another goal of this project is to obtain the spectral characterization of all measures on the real line for which the logarithmic integral converges. This condition, known as the Szego condition, plays a key role in the theory of Gaussian stochastic processes with continuous time. The project also aims to develop spectral theory based on the theory of multiple orthogonal polynomials. In addition, the project will explore wave propagation in multidimensional electromagnetic and acoustic scattering, investigating the minimal assumptions on coefficients in elliptic operators that guarantee existence of wave operators and presence of absolutely continuous spectral type.  The questions to be addressed are central for analysis; the results are expected to have impact in probability, mathematical physics, and other areas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of this award span the core areas of analysis, such as complex and harmonic analysis, and approximation theory. The obtained results established some new connections between different fields. For example, the recently discovered relation between the multiple orthogonal polynomials and the Jacobi matrices on trees provides insights into the spectral analysis of such operators. These findings might have an impact on the theoretical discoveries in quantum physics when sharp analytical methods are required. The study of scattering theory for canonical systems using advanced methods of complex analysis led to a better understanding of such a classical object as a vibrating string, the object whose mathematical investigations date back at least to Thomas Stieltjes. In particular, PI and his collaborator established the necessary and sufficient conditions for the mass distribution of the vibrating string to allow the ballistic wave transport. The refined tools of the complex and harmonic analysis proved to be indispensable when obtaining the best possible mathematical results that explain some basic physics phenomena.

The important part of the work focused on mentoring graduate students and postdocs. The REU summer school in 2023 was organized for a group of UW-Madison students and it was a success. The broader impact of this award included the dissemination of results at conferences and seminars.
